drupalNodeEvent.title: The Debate over New Forms of Capitalism in Japan and the US

field_speakers.processed:
• Gen Goto, Prof. of Law at University of Tokyo
  • Curtis Milhaupt, Prof. of Law at Stanford Law School
  • Bruce Aronson (moderator), Senior Advisor to the Japan Center at the U.S.-Asia Law Institute and adjunct professor at NYU School of Law

field_organizers.processed: U.S.-Asia Law Institute at NYU School of Law and APEC Study Center at Columbia University

field_description.processed: In many advanced countries, traditional forms of capitalism have increasingly come under criticism as contributing to economic and social inequality and failing to serve the needs of society. To address these shortcomings, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is proposing a “new form of capitalism” for the country. In the US, business leaders talk about promoting “stakeholder capitalism” over “shareholder capitalism.” Law Professors Gen Goto and Curtis J. Milhaupt will discuss the similarities and differences between these two sets of ideas and the implications for corporate governance and society.
